y 1, 2014
												This game, although no longer being updated by Hi-Rez, is one of the best FPS titles on the market. It has high quality graphics, 9 different classes, and a free to play system that is less Pay-2-Win than most.Pros:-The game looks great-Tons of different weapons and items to unlock-No Storyline so maximum replayability-A community much better than COD or those types of games-Gameplay that is often based on skillCons:-The system may not be Pay-2-Win, but paying for the Game of the Year gives noobs an advantage over other noobs because certain unlockables are straight upgrades.-The classes are NOT balanced. Certain classes are ridiculously strong while others are borderline underpowered. That being said, a pro can make any of these classes work but they would do better using a good class-Although generally based on skill, some of the more overpowered classes simply rely on pressing a button to win-Weapons are not balanced either, with stock weapons that aren't even used.-Unlocks cost an exceptional amount. Certain unlocks that are required to play a subclass (Chaser on Pathfinder for example) require you to earn over 40 games worth of exp.That being said, this game is still a great FPS, easily kicking COD and those cookie-cutters right off the map.

ber 17, 2013
												I've played a variety of competitive multiplayer shooters throughout my gaming life and I have to say that Tribes: Ascend is easily my favorite of them all. The main attraction is their "Capture the Flag" mode, which is the most intense game of CTF one will ever experience due to the game's unique playing style: a mix of futuritsic "skiing" or "gliding" over vast mountainous playing fields at high speeds. Combine that with precise and challenging shooting at the correct angle and direction to hit the other opponent and finally the correct tactics and timing for offense and defense between your teammates and the opposing force. To top it all off, the game also has excellent graphics, sound, and a fairly large multiplayer community. The game is free to play and upgraded weapons and other items can be unlocked through normal play time, but you can unlock things early through their online store. If you're looking for your next great multiplayer shooter that will challenge you a little more than the average Call of Duty or something similar, then this is your game and it wont cost you a penny! My only major gripe with the game is that they made the red team's armor look very menacing and cool where as the blue team's armor is sort of "light" looking like padding on a soccer player or something. As a result, a lot of players always play as the red team because they hate the look of blue team and the games will often be in favor of the red team... I really wish the developers would have made red and blue armor look the same to avoid a problem like that... sort of like what Valve did with Team Fortress 2 where both red and blue teams look the same, just different colors. Still as an overall package i think the game deserves a solid 8 or 9 out of 10.

It would be perfect if it wasn't F2P (I would gladly pay full price upfront for all content) but the F2P here isnt that intrusive - you can get by decently without much grinding.This game IS tribes. The jetpacks, disc launchers, and voice binds. Flying over hills at ridiculous speeds and landing a midair hit on someone is really.♥♥♥♥ing.satisyfing. The adrenalin rush of being the flag carrier with 5 enemies chasing you at crazy speeds; it was a dopamine/nostalgia overload on my first play.In hindsight, this game needed to be F2P/grind based in order to build a large enough community to keep the servers worth playing in. I only wish they added more CTF maps.Definitely try this out (or you're missing out).

content:
ry 16, 2015
												Well what is there to say about this game? Sadly sice the game of the year edition was released this means one thing; cashing out. I doubt there will be any new major content or new maps to be honest. But should you get this game just cause it is addicting and pretty fun to play. There are some horrible disadvantages to this game:If you're a new player good luck ranking up cause most likely you'll be going up against more experienced playersRanking up is slow and pretty tediousIt is kind of a pay to win game (Pay money and unlock weapons much easier/ faster)Some of the weapons which are ungodly on the battlefield require 20,000+ xp or an easy 250 gold (Pay to win here)Very challenging and aiming is pretty dificult at the startHave to buy classes with 4,500 xp (4,500 xp is not hard to get)Now they are great redeeming factors to this game:Super fast pacedChallenging but really rewading when you land awesome mid airs on players moving faster than vehiclesA good variety of weapons, perks, loadouts, and specific play styles to classesClasses are fairly balanced (But with right weapons, player, and perks; classes can become unkillable and really broken)Vehicles to add something more to the gameMaps are awesome and layed out pretty nicely (In CTF a team can have a slight advantage depending on team or "tribe")The serversFor me servers have been decent and I haven't had too many issues. Occasional lag spikes and rubber banding but thats something we have to deal with anyways. Oh yeah there are different ranked servers. Novice for the lower levels and regular for the higher players. Higher leveled players cannot join Novice servers unless they join a friend through the in game social system. Once you "leveled out" of the novice servers welcome to dealing with level 30+ players and you'll be fairly miniscule compared to them. When you are "too good" for the Novice servers that is when the game falls of a steep cliff and die. Most servers are sadly empty so good luck finding any action. Novice servers are the only ones that have players in it, but remember you're leveled out.So should you get this game? If you really like fast paced challenging gameplay then pick it up. The thing is though early game will be painful as you will be left with weapons that very "basic" and aren't good or bad. Aquiring weapons, classes, perks, and anything will take a long time. Servers are nice, but the leveling and ranking involved with joining is stupid.I like this game and I still enjoy it today.

												This game is a fantastic combination of teamwork, 3 dimensional movement, precision aiming, and skill. It is exciting and worth a try as a free game. Be mindful that you will probably get wrecked for your first few matches until you develop a sense of how to move, shoot, and be aware of others.It is very high skillcap and enjoyed an eSports following after launch. However, the skillcap also makes it very frustrating to learn and requires a lot of practice (and innate skill) to become truely exceptional. The community, more often than not, can be harsh and critical of new players, even in the low rank servers.Despite the tag, the game is not "Pay 2 Win". Every weapon, kit, and class is unlockable and upgradeable through XP earned during play. It will take a long time, but the 3 initial classes (Pathfinder, Solider, and Juggernaut) are the most effective once you learn to play them. Paying money for Tribes gold is really only necessary if you want special skins or voice packs.Unfortunately the game is "abandonware" and won't continue to see the developer support. Hi-Rez has moved on to their new MOBA game Smite in search of microtransaction profit and has minimal staff overseeing this game.Be warned that the developer's customer service has a poor track record, even for loyal players. HiRez runs an anticheat program as long as the service as up that will detect "undesireable software" running on your computer such as Cheat Engine. Even if that program is not affecting/injecting code into Tribes, it will be sent to the servers for a very quick IP ban and permanent ban on your account. These false positives are almost never reviewed seriously and bans are maintained indefinitely with curt/generic responses to your complaints. The "undesired software" is not explicitly defined and you should use caution when playing while running any software that may affect your game (or any other game - example: ENBInjector for Skyrim originally caused false positives).I recommend this game as a free diversion and exposure to my favorite style of FPS, but caution you not to spend money on it. This game is unlikely to see any major support from Hi-Rez Studios.

												Tribes: Ascend is the most pure representation of the Tribes experience since Tribes 2 perfected it back in 2001. Almost every single part of the experience has been tweaked and improved, classes reborn and expanded, maps detailed and sprawling. You can ski like a master within minutes, but perfecting your routes, jumps and jetpack tactics are still the aim of the game.

er 25, 2012
												RE-REVIEW:Tribes: Ascend is the picture perfect example of free to play gaming. Beautiful graphics, one-of-a-kind and completely original gameplay and a wide variety of unlockable weapons for each of the games nine player classes (Pathfinder, Sentinal, Infiltrator, Soldier, Technician, Raider, Juggernaut, Doombringer, Brute) come together to create a gaming experience that nobody can afford to miss. It's originality can be attributed solely to it's fast paced gameplay, Highrez boasted that it is the worlds fastest first person shooter, and they aren't just saying that for sh*ts-n-gigglez. The high-speed skiing mechanic may appear daunting to first time players, but a simple level-up and matchmaking system ensures that you are matched with players of equal status. And for the record, yes, it IS completely original. Some idiots may be out thinking that it's a ripoff of Halo (see: overrated garbage), but simple facts show that the first Tribes game was released a good two years before Halo was even concieved. However, for all it's originality there are some significant drawbacks. It is as some friends of mine called it: A system hog, and it is NOT recommended for use on machines with minimal RAM, low-end graphics cards and puny processors. As well, to acquire the unlockables you are heavily encouraged to buy them with Tribes Gold, alternatives exist in the form of in-game XP, but the grind to afford one of them is in laymans terms, hell on earth. While it has it's flaws, Tribes: Ascend is an amazing game, and if you're desktop clunker can handle it, give it a go as it is the best F2P game I've played since TF2.***UPDATE***Sadly, HiRez seemingly deemed Tribes: Ascend no longer to be worth their attention, and as a result Tribes has suffered an untimely and unfortunate early shelfing. Making it perfectly clear that they'd rather work on Smite because THAT game is such a blockbusting smash.(I don't have any qualms about the gameplay of Smite, only that it seems to be jumping on the MOBA bandwagon due to the popularity of Valve's Dota 2)

ber 17, 2013
												Tribes: Ascend is a free-to-play game (though money is needed for some features) which surpasses all expectations one could have for a shooting game. Most shooting games put the players in a slow-paced environment where the desire to move quicker than 7 mph is not an option. In this game, if you're moving slower than that, it's because you're standing still.This game requires a good aim, reflex, tracking, and anticipation. Most of your gameplay will require that you anticipate. There are enormous hills all over the place, and between the "skiing" and jetpack abilities, there's really no way you'll have to NOT anticipate before shooting.It also features several cameos and essences I really enjoy, even one relating directly to Sonic the Hedgehog (the best video game series ever). Several voices and  statements and whatnot from prior games were dragged into this game, and better yet, you can control the exact statement you use, unlike previous games in the Tribes series.As a First-Person Shooter game, I give it a 10/10, hands down. Most shooters I play get around 5/10. As a video game altogether, I give it 9/10, graphics and physics and originality and whatever else factors all considered. From a PERSONAL standpoint, I give it a 6/10. It's something I like to play, but not very often. Games are meant for fun, aaaaaaaaaand that's how I tend to rate games on a personal level. This game is a LOT of fun, especially to someone who hasn't played a Tribes game in 9 years or so when they find out this one is free. VGW

												Switching to Steam version, thought I'd drop an opinion here.This game is fun in itself, and different from most bland shooters. You go fast, fast, fast, and you shoot high explosives. And I'm afraid that's where praise must end. HiRez doesn't give you anything noticable that you can get shortly, like in Blacklight Retribution or Spiral Knights. Instead, all upgrades are crutch weapons, things a class NEEDS to operate properly, after weeks of saving up from wins. There are severe class imbalances, such as Doombringer being useless overall and Infiltrators' capabilities of killing you instantly from their cloaks, and so on. It's something to play. It's very pay-to-win, free players mostly being cannon fodder. Until these issues are fixed, I wouldn't recommend paying a cent.It's still fun to play on occasion, hence why I haven't deleted it yet.Edit: As of 12/13/2013, I haven't played this game in, what, a year or so? If what I read is true, they've abandoned development and the game is still subject to some very serious balancing problems, especially in that new players simply can't compete. But really, the only reason I updated this was to change the recommendation from yes to no now that Steam has a system like that.

r 22, 2012
												Edit: DO NOT GET THIS GAME. As of last year, Hi-Rez has stopped all support for this game, and no longer updates nor polices it. The legitimate players have long since quit en masse, leaving only cheaters and hackers to fill the now-sparsely populated servers. I've been meaning to edit this review for a while now, but I've been putting it off for later until today. Hi-Rez has abandoned one game after another to focus on their newest cash grab (at the time of this writing, they're working on Smite).Tribes: Ascend is the fastest FPS game in the market. Everyone is encased in highly mobile power armor that lets them fight at blazing fast speed on the ground or in the air. In this game, a character running and gunning at 100 kph (62 mph for my fellow Americans) is considered slow, and skilled characters can engage in 250+ kph (155 +mph) firefights. To further complicate things, there are very few hitscan weapons in this game, and all of the automatic weapons are projectile based. A fast-paced game with a high skill ceiling.I recommend buying the 90-day XP booster, which is on sale for 1600 gold at the time of this writing (October 22, 2012). A VIP account (one that has paid anything) gets +50% XP. The booster doubles your XP on top of the +50%, for a total of triple XP (+200%) for 90 days and +50% XP once it wears off. You also get a bonus 1,200 XP per day that the XP booster is active, giving you even more XP to spend.Also, on Facebook, you can get 250 gold for liking it.

y 21, 2014
												EDIT: The Out of the Blue patch has improved this game immensely, bringing it more in line with Tribes and Tribes 2. However, there still are some balance issues, but much more concerning is the still-dwindling player base. Hi Rez has shown they've not completely forgotten about the game, but now they need to show they're commited to actually making it a good one. Check out all the new changes, and keep an eye on the game. Hopefully things continue to improve.An interesting title that's more a mixed bag than anything. Flashy graphics and unique mechanics provide lots of fun, but the massive xp costs for the countless amount of unlocks turns what would be a solid FPS into a frustrating grind fest. Not to mention, the learning curve is extremely steep; between learning all the weapon behaviors and skiing, there's a rather large barrier of entry for a newcomer. However, the DOTA- and CS-like difficulty is compounded by the xp grind and feeling of helplessness against those who have arguably "better" unlocks and more time with the game. Granted, mastering skiing and grinding for the unlocks will certainly keep you coming back, the former being genuinely fun and the latter having the same addictiveness for completionists.The classic F2P microtransation system really forces you to start pumping money in to bolster your arsenal. You'll have so little if you solely unlock through grinding that you're likely to never know what you actually prefer otherwise. For those inclined to do so can use Steam Wallet funds to purchase Tribes Gold in-game. This allows you to unlock weapons, classes and perks much faster than by grinding alone.However, putting money into this does leave a bad taste in your mouth. The game does feel like it's slowly expiring, so spending money on the myriad of arguably better and/or necessary unlocks also quickly kills the desire to play. Having dropped $20 in my 30 hours of play has left me little fulfillment. More often than not, I'll want to play, but the sense of aversion due to the xp grind and complete chaos in pubs keeps me from hitting the play button now.Hackers are both stupidly obvious and game breaking. One will ruin a game entirely; ironically, this is usually the best way to grind xp. Furthermore, despite the potential for large and hectic matches, even the normal 12vs12 games feel sparsely populated, every player preferring to go at it lone-wolf. This frequently results in both team having one or two players with better unlocks capping uninterrupted or camping your generator. The only time it feels like people are truly working together is when it's hardcore players stomping your team.Vehicles also don't seem to be touched at all, another disappointment considering the amazing potential they can have. The vehicle pad screams for more attention. Of the three (yes, only three - that doesn't even fill the list space!) vehicles you can purchase during a match, two are bland, expected additions that most games in this genre will have. The Grav Cycle is the best of the three, but still pales compared to other vehicles seen in FPS games in the past decade.I find myself picking it up every so often because despite its issues I really do want to enjoy this game. As you perfect your skiing and get better at predicting shots, there is some degree of redemption afforded the game? Those one-in-a-million shots are extremely gratifying, and high-speed chases are thrilling. Unfortunately, for a game so young, it seems to be suffering from the same fate many significantly older games are: a dwindling player base and no new official content. While Tribes fans may be able to look past the flaws to play a game bearing the series name with a modern paintjob, after a certain point the enjoyment of mid-air spinfusor directs simply can't produce enough draw to boot the game again. Whether that's after 5, 50, or 500 hours is dependent on how much you like the franchise.Sadly, Tribes: Ascend is only really recommendable to the intensely curious who won't mind the grinding and frustration or the long-time fans who'll buy the GOTY version. For a game with so much potential, it really feels the weight of its awards have crushed it. It's had its 15 minutes of fame and has ceased being profitable for the developer. Without a support team to keep it patched, hacker free, and fresh with new content, Tribes: Ascend is simply crumbling under its own weight.I love this game but it hates me. The Tribes franchise deserved better.

9, 2014
												I Really hate to see games that have so much potential and fall flat on its face. Don't get me wrong, I like the idea for this game, I really do. And for a while that game worked and had a big following, But Hi-Rez have completely ruined there own game in this case. First of all, the graphics feel like last gen graphics (Even on max settings) which isn't good seeing as how the game is only a year old, next you have bad texture pop in, lag and environmental glitches. All of which could have easily been fixed with patches and routine updates, but Hi-Rez have stopped updates for this game to focus on SMITE (Ironically, its suffering the same fate as Tribes: Ascend). But if you're willing to look past the bad graphics (Gameplay over Graphics) the game does work, skiing, vehicles, jetpacks etc. work like they are supposed to, however trying to get accustomed to using them well in a game is impossible, because the community of new players is dead, leaving only Tribes veterans, that will wipe the floor with you giving you virtually no chance to improve at your own pace. and to make matters worse, the training section is a joke, they have a few options, basic skiing, free roam, practice with bots (F.Y.I. the training with bots isn't a full match like you'd think, its just the bots running back and forth in set direction or not moving around at all) or watching youtube videos explaining the classes. To me that is just lazy. And even thought they have servers of novices only, nothing stops a level 32 veteran from connecting to the server and demolishing all the level 1-7 novices; once again stopping all progress to get better at your own pace. All in all, don't get this game, it was great at one point but unfortunately we are all a year too late from it heyday. the only way I could recommend this game is if you're a tribes veteran, which most of us are not

ry 8, 2015
												A free to play, play to win game.I use to play Tribes back when it first came out around 2000. It had awesome gameplay, and a ton of mods that kept you interested. There was no leveling up, everyone had access to the same classes, weapons, and accessories. You played to win, and the community was amazing. The game had it's own in-system IRC chat, where you could get help, have fun, or even get recruited into a tribe (clan). They had rankings for the best tribe for each mod, which were determined by scheduled matches. Tribes was my first online gaming love. Unfortunately I don't think I will ever find that level of awesomeness again. Franchise has just seemed to go down hill since the original. This latest installment makes me sad. If you want to play on a versatile and competative level, like the original offered, you either have to spend money, or grind days, probably even weeks, worth of gameplay to get enough exp to achieve it. Also, the support for the game appears to have totally vanished.

y 14, 2015
												TL;DR (even tho this isn't long anyway): Tribes theoretically is a waste of time on the long term, but you should have at least tried it and seen the awesome, unique mechanics this game introduced. If you've got time to spare and feel like playing around for a couple hours, this'll do great. You might get disappointed/sad once you realise how much ♥♥♥♥ the devs did outside of gameplay.Tribes probably wrote the saddest FPS story I've witnessed.It's so sad, I'm not gonna make a long explanation out of it. It's a story of how the most promising and fun gameplay concepts got overshadowed by ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dev decisions, especially outside of direct gameplay.My actual recommendation: At least try this game, if you haven't. Why? Because you should have seen it. I don't think it's an actually recommendable game on the long term, but compare this game's gameplay to a lame ♥♥♥, boring CoD or whatever (those kind of shooters where the concept clearly is "shooting > strategies"). Tribes does have a strategic part to it, but the shooting part is done in such a unique and fun way, it's ridiculous. Whenever I play a FPS that's promoted as "fast", fun or individual and I try it, all I think is "well, it's not Tribes". Hardly any game has similarly entertaining and unique mechanics in it. Balance issues, a kind of p2w system, no mod support and updates that didn't add ♥♥♥♥ to the game make me not want to play this anymore, but I'll never forget the ♥♥♥♥ing sick concepts and potential this game had.

ber 22, 2014
												During its release it was a spectacular phenomenon with exceptionally balanced combat mechanics and gameplay. Movement feels fluid as it ever has in the tribes series, and graphically it is a marvel with brilliant skyboxes, particle effects, and motion blur. A sheer joy, it was a rare game where being just a spectator was enjoyable. But now, depressingly I might add, after tens of thousands of game hours spent Hi-Rez decided to shut down game development and with it any kind of support. Servers have been in a laggy mess ever sense and anything other than a pub match is impossible. Combat balance is long gone with all the added weapons for multiple classes creating upgrades rather than sidegrade options for those willing to purchase them. Hi-Rez made a miserable mess of this game that had so much potential, and left the cult like following of it with barely a trace other than a slightly lighter wallet.

												"Some AimBots, but not a lot. A good spin-off to the original Tribes. Shotgun range is a little TOO far, but meh. Not a ton of players, so you'll constanly be playing w/ the same players in Arena. (Oh, and don't be surprised by all the Assault Rifle type weapon spam.)"This is a quote of my original review. I have not played for quite some time and there is a reason for that. I absolutely loved the original Tribes, so I had no problem supporting the game through micro-transactions. However, when you do so, you don't expect what the developers of Tribes: Ascend did. Little by little I spent a decent chunk of money on new items as they were relased, whether it was IG currency saved up or using RL funds. I supported the game.However, the developers released a package in which you could unlock everything currently in the game for one astronomically low price. This is an insult to anyone that has been devoted to the game from the start. At the time I had every weapon, minus two or three that had literally just been released. In turn, this means that new players that have just purchased the game have better gear unlocked then I do, in one fell swoop.I lost all faith in the developers after seeing this package and felt nothing more than having been used.

												A solid fast paced FPS that is by far the best CTF game mode in any FPS ever. The speed and intense gameplay are second to none, and the game is utterly mesmerising to play at a high level. The game however has suffered from the developers decision with additions that destroyed a lot of the games balance and ruined many of the classes roles. Before then abandoning it for another IP they had also been creating (SMITE). This is a sad thing due to the potential the game had right from the start. With a solid base like it had at launch the game could have well been one of the premiere competitive FPS games out there. With a large playerbase it fundimentally was already there, but the poor balancing and choice of weapons fundimentally ruined the game and it's current state is not much fun.I'd like it if HI-Rez actually did come back and resolved the games concurrent issues and took it foward. That or another company got the rights to the Tribes brand and developed it. I'd gladly drop more money on this game any day, if it was developed with the proper care and attention to the game itself.

												Tribes: Ascend is probably the most fun you can have with online multiplayer. It's consistently fast paced and furious, with players zipping around on jetpacks and various destructive vehicles such as hoverbikes, tanks, and fighter aircraft. Seriously, stop reading this and download the damn game!

er 18, 2013
												This game, had potential.The main flaw is literally the F2P model. Obviously they have to make money somehow, but all we end up with is a TF2 style game with lots of pointless classes that u have to level (and then comes the requirement to pay to compete). The game in my opinion would be better with a single class, the pathfinder as it's fun and requires skill to use and can complete all the different objectives in the game, such as flag defense and offense.The addition of generators and turrets that need repairing is really not that useful. The tech spends most time repairing (it takes 30+ seconds to repair) but it takes 5 seconds to destroy by the "infiltrator" (aka spy) class which can remain hidden for a fair time. So, it takes the tech 1 min 30+ to repair what took the spy class 15 seconds. Eventually you feel it's not worth the effort anymore. Sometimes you can spent ages having a battle with the spy or 2, not even getting outside of the generator room the entire game.The heavy class, can sit outside the range of the turrets and destroy them from long range, obsoleting the point of turrets. Another flaw that makes the tech slightly redundant.The soldier class has a thumper (aka a sort of grenade launcher) and IIRC a machine gun, making it way stronger than the pathfinder, at least at lower levels.The problem with all the other classes is they are too imba and don't require skill. Unfortunately you can find yourself being pummelled by someone who has a weapon with a higher dispersal or a rapid fire weapon, such as SMGs or even chain guns (machine guns).There is in fact, no need to go faster in this game because the strongest and most imba classes are the slower ones!This game will never become big because the "levelling" element makes it unsuitable for competitive play and the lack of a level playing field, where the difference is in the players skill.

2, 2014
												I bought the closed beta in October 2011, and having never played any of the original tribes I was hooked. The game was a whole different ballgame than what I've played in the last 15 years. Having come from military shooters, with the exception of some co-op and TF2, I was looking forward to the projectile game as that's all I cared for in TF2 and I never got big in to quake either back in the day. When T:A went F2P I -- like most closed beta -- had high hopes it would be 'the next big thing' but boy we were wrong. As time went on and the game expanded you realized the developers had no idea about anything at all. Map Designers had no logic in their design, no maps made sense as to where you may find assets / repair guns / vehicle pads / inventory stations. Some maps do not even offer vehicles (not talking ones with them disabled). While it's not terribly hard to play the maps a few times and learn them you'll find yourself irritated so much with the fact there's no standardized design for maps. Suiciding will become your friend.After you make peace with terrible map design (to be fair 20-33% aren't too bad, but all lack consistancy you'll find in every major fps) you'll come to realize that the weapons are super inbalanced. The game started off with pretty much projectiles, save the inf (no one used it) and soldier AR. As time moved on everyone got machine guns. This was a big blow to the game in term of longetivity and probably is the main reason it's died. Not only were none of the maps designed with such weapons in everyones hands (no cover to hide from the literal 1-5k bullet spam per 20 seconds) but using a [timed] health regen system on top makes regending impossible unless you camp your base (which is why all pub games are defense).Anyone who has time logged knows autos are super easy to use, because they have no recoil, no spread. The only one which is implemented in a great way is the pathfinder lar -- because it's limited to 3 shot burst , and with a from-beta-possibly-alpha bug of dry firing you can bank on the person missing a few shots from it not actually firing.So on top of horrible map design, and imbalanced/spam weapons not compatable with map terrain or the health system you'll find a few other things that are a bit messed up like the snipers. You'll come to find out about this game there's a few things: Hi-Rez thinks the 2% of people who pug (or "compete" if you want to call it that) are the only people who play here. if you've ever seen a 'competitive' tribes game you'll see 2 things: endless auto spam, and cappers so terrible that the best strategy is to 'punt the flag'. It's why competitve t:a never took off and the only people who play(ed) it are people who can't let go of the game. Oh yes, back to the pug voice dictacting the game flow. So one thing you'll know if you've been around a long time is that snipers are terrible. Terribly easy to play, terribly imbalanced, and have absolutely no place in this game as it sits. They, like most things, were added because 'chasing is too hard for the autospam/flag punting 2%'. I put only a few dozen hours in to sentinel if that and I could consistantly hit the top 5 clans in the game (s1-2) @ 300-400 sanics no problem. The problem with the sniper isn't the 1-3 shot ability; it's that the class generally isn't in any danger because they camp far back. T:A was supposed to be about action, not d stacks and sent camps because no one can catch the flag guy (too logical to fix cap speeds). On top of this, you have numerous bugs still existing from beta, and many of the glitches such as rock bounces added as 'features' due to , again, the 2%. -- This was when I quit.Now, 3 weeks ago I started playing again with a friend. Sad to say, it got worse. If you're lucky you'll find 5-10 servers with people on them, only to find 1/2 of them are level restricted to 1-10. So you fight over queueing in to 1 of 3-4 servers with the same people. All of them spamming automatics endlessly and spamming the VGS system. You'll see pubstar cappers ending games in 5-0s trying to look good but failing to realize the entire t:a population of < 500 people aren't too interested in capping a flag. Yes, I know, it's CTF. But that's because no other servers exist, and the only TDM I saw was 1-10 restricted.So, that about sums up this game. It's totally fun to tinker with casually, but it's never anything to take seriously. The developers used it as a cash cow to fund their next game then dumped it, no mod support even as a thank you. They quit supporting it in June 2013 so it is what it is and that's not much.I still enjoy tanking auto noobs and blue plating people but you'll find yourself wondering why the same people you see in every server haven't learned how to shoot a projectile well by now.

												Tribes Ascend is a brilliantly fast but not fast-paced shooter that requires accuracy over awareness. The map is extremely open and you feel really bawesome skiing and jetpacking your way extremely quickly through an enemy fort. This is really tricky to stop but also satisfying, and you don't just have your fast battles requiring accuracy. When you try to shut down the enemy generator to limit their powers, that means that you can have the normal types of battles you are used to, and you can use the slower more explode-y weapons. The vehicles some say are underwhelming, and that depends on how they are priced. There's the slow tanky beowulf, the fast motorbike, and the shrike, which is your flying vehicle that is not for everyone. The call-ins are probably better. You can make recourse drops and also call in slow but extremely powerful strikes from the air.

												Tribes: Ascend is a strange case. The game was wonderful once, even I have to dare to call it an example of the perfect FPS. The main game mode was capture the flag and it had a small variety of weapons, including the spinfusor. The spinfusor projectiles could inherit the speed of the user, leading to a desicion from the player: do they go fast and make it more difficult to hit things or slow down and be more difficult to hit. As such, a typical game would be: Defenders set up minimal defences Flag cappers gain enough speed using skis, jetpack and boosters to get past the automated turrets and opposing players Flag carriers cap flag by going fastThe game revolved around the skiing mechanic, in which one could go fast by activating skis down hill but had to use a jetpack uphill. This led to the game being FAST. About a year ago, the developer introduced a speed cap for flag carriers, a change to how inheritence of projectile weapons was calculated, a buff to the heavy classes and then suddenly stopped development of the game altogether because they wanted to hop onto the MOBA bandwagon. I apologise to people who only just heard of this game but it's too late, it's dead now. If there was more marketing other than none whatsoever or it went to Steam earlier maybe people would have jumped on it before it died.STAY CLEAR OF THIS GAME AND ANYTHING ELSE THE DEVELOPER MAKES, THEY ARE GREEDY SCUMBAGS.

												One of the most awesome FPS games to come out in a long time. It has Jetpacks, that should be enough to convince you for starters, but if it's not, then it's also one of the only games where almost none of the wepons are hitscan, everything fires actual projectiles, even SMG's, so you have to lead and predict targets adding a much needed boost to skill ceiling and satisfaction on success that FPS games have been lacking lately. Nothing beats the feeling of landing that long range mid-air spinfusor shot. You can also get a bit of a boost to unlocking stuff by liking tribes on facebook and signing up for the game using a refferal link like https://account.hirezstudios.com/tribesascend/♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥=1322159&utm_campaign=email to get you some bonus XP at level 6 (and me too). The game has enough depth that I would reccomend making use of the skiing tutorial and target practice in game. Come play so I have fools to shoot!

, 2014
												This game is a free fast-paced FPS with mostly ballistic weapons and awesome movement mechanics including jetpacks and a complete friction loss from the ground. And because gliding + hills + speed + ballistic weapons = hard to hit, this game is difficult. And awesome.Now to get a little more precise, the movement can be compared with the little iOS game tiny wings, where you slide through the little gaps between round hills and fly around as fast as you can, but this is 3D. The weapons are mostly in one of these 3 categories: Explosive weapons fire slowly, have rather slowly flying projectiles with splash damage and extreme damage on a direct hit, while bullet based guns (autos) fire rather fast flying little projectiles dealing high damage per second if you manage to hit all shots and the usually weakest but easy to aim hitscan weapons, which work as all guns do in "modern shooters". You point at an enemy and when you click, they die.As you may have guessed, to be good at the game you should be able to handle guns from the first category, which are the way it's meant to be played and the only real honorable option (Debatable, I know, discuss it on reddit or whatever). The fast movement is hard to control in the beginning and hitting fast people with ballistic weapons can be extremely hard. This is what puts game's skill ceiling so high.The community is not as big as it used to be, by now the game is slowly dying ( http://steamcharts.com/app/17080#All ). Still, there's always enough EU servers filled to join in a suitable game for me, so I will be enjoying the game for a long time. The good players are friendly to each other, the few toxic parts of the community are found in low-level servers and quit plaing sooner or later. Your first matches will be on these novice servers, although you will soon reach level 10 just to be thrown into games with the seasoned veterans when you know little about the game but the basics. This makes it even harder for new players.So, to come to a conclusion:The game is awesome, but difficult.We can use more new players learning with each other instead of getting wrecked by pros, so give it a try.What you can have for free is one of the best multiplayer shooters out there.Prepare to get owned! Don't be frustrated, it's bound to happen.Continue playing and think about what you do, learn from the enemy and you will get better.Have fun!

												It's pretty good after you unlock your first two classes, but before that (and even after), the game is extremely hard to master, as everyone else has super upgraded weapons, perks and other stuff. Vehicles can be acquired by spending "XP" earned in matches (XP resets every match). This game is good enough that I still play it, but IMO, the match-making should be better. I keep being set into games that have people that are 20 or something ranks ahead of me.Good points:-JETPACKS!-Unique Ski mechanic that lets you fly through the map barely touching the ground.-Great inertia/velocity physics-Requires skill-Recent update made things cheaper-Interesting weaponsBad points:-Dwindling population-Terrible, if any, matchmaking-Requires skill-Things are still pricy-Lack of support from the devs (they've moved on).Misc. points:-There are almost no hitscan weapons, meaning you have to lead your shots and use your brain to calculate/anticipate/predict where your enemy will be by the time your shot reaches them.-No ADS. It's either zoom or hipfire, much like Halo.-If you don't ski and/or use your jetpack, and play this like CoD or Battlefield, you're gonna be dead quick.-The maps are large, so you'll need to use your enhanced movement to get around quicker.tl:dr: Much better than Smite, although the developer has abandoned the game.

												This game, although no longer being updated by Hi-Rez, is one of the best FPS titles on the market. It has high quality graphics, 9 different classes, and a free to play system that is less Pay-2-Win than most.Pros:-The game looks great-Tons of different weapons and items to unlock-No Storyline so maximum replayability-A community much better than COD or those types of games-Gameplay that is often based on skillCons:-The system may not be Pay-2-Win, but paying for the Game of the Year gives noobs an advantage over other noobs because certain unlockables are straight upgrades.-The classes are NOT balanced. Certain classes are ridiculously strong while others are borderline underpowered. That being said, a pro can make any of these classes work but they would do better using a good class-Although generally based on skill, some of the more overpowered classes simply rely on pressing a button to win-Weapons are not balanced either, with stock weapons that aren't even used.-Unlocks cost an exceptional amount. Certain unlocks that are required to play a subclass (Chaser on Pathfinder for example) require you to earn over 40 games worth of exp.That being said, this game is still a great FPS, easily kicking COD and those cookie-cutters right off the map.

er 25, 2012
												RE-REVIEW:Tribes: Ascend is the picture perfect example of free to play gaming. Beautiful graphics, one-of-a-kind and completely original gameplay and a wide variety of unlockable weapons for each of the games nine player classes (Pathfinder, Sentinal, Infiltrator, Soldier, Technician, Raider, Juggernaut, Doombringer, Brute) come together to create a gaming experience that nobody can afford to miss. It's originality can be attributed solely to it's fast paced gameplay, Highrez boasted that it is the worlds fastest first person shooter, and they aren't just saying that for sh*ts-n-gigglez. The high-speed skiing mechanic may appear daunting to first time players, but a simple level-up and matchmaking system ensures that you are matched with players of equal status. And for the record, yes, it IS completely original. Some idiots may be out thinking that it's a ripoff of Halo (see: overrated garbage), but simple facts show that the first Tribes game was released a good two years before Halo was even concieved. However, for all it's originality there are some significant drawbacks. It is as some friends of mine called it: A system hog, and it is NOT recommended for use on machines with minimal RAM, low-end graphics cards and puny processors. As well, to acquire the unlockables you are heavily encouraged to buy them with Tribes Gold, alternatives exist in the form of in-game XP, but the grind to afford one of them is in laymans terms, hell on earth. While it has it's flaws, Tribes: Ascend is an amazing game, and if you're desktop clunker can handle it, give it a go as it is the best F2P game I've played since TF2.***UPDATE***Sadly, HiRez seemingly deemed Tribes: Ascend no longer to be worth their attention, and as a result Tribes has suffered an untimely and unfortunate early shelfing. Making it perfectly clear that they'd rather work on Smite because THAT game is such a blockbusting smash.(I don't have any qualms about the gameplay of Smite, only that it seems to be jumping on the MOBA bandwagon due to the popularity of Valve's Dota 2)

Well, I guess even a static player with a sniper weapon (class: Sentinel).YAY, finally a worthwhile multiplayer FPS

, 2014
												I've spent over 500 hours on this game, having had no experience with the previous games in the franchise, and I can say one thing about it that I'm completely sure of: It's very, very good.Hirez made a fantastic shooter, that, in spite of its high critical acclaim and praise, never managed to secure an audience large enough to merit its continued development, and caused it to only exist as a "live" game for a year after coming out of open beta. The studio got a lot of flak for moving its focus over to another risky endeavour, which is the MOBA Smite, which paid off after Smite saw a lot of commercial success and propelled the studio from a small 20-man staff to employing over 80 people. I recommend playing Tribes: Ascend without hesitation, as it is the best online shooter I've ever played, and in spite of some balancing issues, and lack of studio support, I will continue playing for as long as the servers don't burst into flames and die, at which point the game will probably die too. Go in, have fun, shoot people, and try not to rage too much when hyper-skilled players gun you down with automatic weapons 4 times over. It's a lot of fun if you play it for fun.

ry 15, 2014
												This game is a fantastic combination of teamwork, 3 dimensional movement, precision aiming, and skill. It is exciting and worth a try as a free game. Be mindful that you will probably get wrecked for your first few matches until you develop a sense of how to move, shoot, and be aware of others.It is very high skillcap and enjoyed an eSports following after launch. However, the skillcap also makes it very frustrating to learn and requires a lot of practice (and innate skill) to become truely exceptional. The community, more often than not, can be harsh and critical of new players, even in the low rank servers.Despite the tag, the game is not "Pay 2 Win". Every weapon, kit, and class is unlockable and upgradeable through XP earned during play. It will take a long time, but the 3 initial classes (Pathfinder, Solider, and Juggernaut) are the most effective once you learn to play them. Paying money for Tribes gold is really only necessary if you want special skins or voice packs.Unfortunately the game is "abandonware" and won't continue to see the developer support. Hi-Rez has moved on to their new MOBA game Smite in search of microtransaction profit and has minimal staff overseeing this game.Be warned that the developer's customer service has a poor track record, even for loyal players. HiRez runs an anticheat program as long as the service as up that will detect "undesireable software" running on your computer such as Cheat Engine. Even if that program is not affecting/injecting code into Tribes, it will be sent to the servers for a very quick IP ban and permanent ban on your account. These false positives are almost never reviewed seriously and bans are maintained indefinitely with curt/generic responses to your complaints. The "undesired software" is not explicitly defined and you should use caution when playing while running any software that may affect your game (or any other game - example: ENBInjector for Skyrim originally caused false positives).I recommend this game as a free diversion and exposure to my favorite style of FPS, but caution you not to spend money on it. This game is unlikely to see any major support from Hi-Rez Studios.

												Oh gods Tribes Ascend. This would be one of the best games I've ever played if it weren't for the ridiculously high skill requirement. It isn't even a learning curve, it's a time commitment. You have to first get a feel for Skiing - the primary means of getting around a map - then you have to learn how to use at least one of the game's weapons, all of which are hard to use. Mastering one of the game's weapons is akin to earning your 5th degree black belt, both in terms of effort and timecomitted to it, as well as the effectiveness that results from your mastery. I have yet to come close to even becoming adept with one of the weapons in this game. Another thing is that the lag, even though it is miniscule and very well covered up by lag compensation, will MESS WITH YOU. A 0.2-second delay in firing your Spinfusor means the difference between scoring a direct hit and accidentally killing yourself in the explosion. Another thing is that the class balance is a bit off-kilter; Medium and Heavy classes can easily travel 9/10ths the speed of a Light class, and their weapons can one-hit Light classes with splash damage. Whereas, the Light classes have to score nothing but direct hits to even come close to leaving an engagement with their lives. It's not a huge issue; the Light's job is to run around sewing chaos, not engaging directly, but it can get under your fingernails when a misfired shell kills you instantly after you walk out of the spawn area.Besides that the game really is deservent of the title of "The fastest FPS on the market." With practice, you can easily reach racecar speeds of 300 KPH on a regular basis; I've seen some people get up to a supersonic 600 KPH when they try. The skill-based weapons are both rewarding and aggravating at the same time; you can go an entire match without a single kill or assist because of how bad your aiming skills are, and the next match you can rack up 10 mid-air kills with grenades. It's entirely dependent on how good you are, how bad the lag is, and whether or not the gods of hilarious killshots are on your side. The team balance isn't stellar, but there is at least an algorithm that exists to balance out teams. All of the gamemodes are stupid fun, and teamwork does matter even if you hardly ever get it. This game is a proponent of the "Awesome Moment"; you know, those time where there is 1 minute left in the game, you're playing as Pathfinder, the most fragile class in the game, and you skii into the enemy's flag room, kill 3 guys in one shot, grab the flag right before the enemy team captures theirs, kill the flag carrier and return your flag, skii all the way home dodging missiles and AA fire as you deftly slide up and down ramps and hills, and just before the game ends, you cap the flag and tie the game. Much Shazbot will be heard.

r 7, 2012
												Since HiRez *FINALLY* released a patch for this game, after two whole years, I figured it was time to patch my review.  While everyone figured they abandoned the game (which, they pretty much did for a while there), they came out of no where with this new patch.  And it puts the feel of the old school Tribes games back in.  Gone are the individual classes, back with just the light/medium/heavy sets and customizable loadouts.  There's been a slew of quality improvements as well as a couple new maps.  I definitely feel like I'm playing a graphically and mechanically updated version of the beloved Starsiege Tribes from the late 90s, which is fantastic.  A lot of F2P games get you with their IAPs and P2W, but even HiRez has admitted they're not going to make money off this patch.  They've basically given the old players everything in the game completely unlocked.  You shouldn't spend more than $10 on the game unless you're just impatient, as it appears everything (except armor skins and voice packs) are unlockable via XP.  I can't not recommend this game to fans of the FPS genre, because the bottom line is it's just that good.

4, 2014
												A great game.HISTORY:Tribes is an old franchise that goes all the way to 1999 with Starsiege: Tribes. It differentiated itself from other futuristic shooters by having wide open maps, vehicles, class system (similar to what Battlefield 1942 did 3 years later) and jetpacks. Then later on, Tribes 2 came and further expanded on the idea, adding skiing (which is one of the few cases of a bug becoming a core feature of a franchise). It was well received and a couple of years later, Tribes: Vengeance came out and it was the first attempt to try streamlining the formula, however it wasn't well received by fans. And so, Tribes IP languished year after year, at one time developer called GarageGames (who made Fallen Empire: Legions, heavily (by heavily I mean almost completely copied) inspired by Tribes) bought the IP with the intent of remaking Tribes 1 for their InstantAction platform (which might be defunct now), til Hi-Rez bought the rights and set on to develop Tribes: Ascend.BASICS:Tribes: Ascend can be best described as "Battlefield meets Halo, fast-paced". It is a first-person shooter which pits teams Blood Eagle between treacherous Diamond Sword, each team can have max. 14 players with 3 armor classes in disposal. It is very team-oriented (as you might've noticed) and each player needs to accomodate and communicate between teammates to win. It's not as easy to learn as other games in the genre, you need to have at least some knowledge of the game, but it is gratifying as you soar into the sky with your jetpack and then ski 200 km/h (or is it mph), get into duels and so on.GAME MODES:There are many game types you can play, however the main type of Tribes: Ascend is Capture-the-flag. Each team fights for other team's flag and 5 captured flags end the game or if the time runs out with the score difference of two or one without other team holding the flag. Team Deathmatch is also widely played and recommended for newbies to try out. There are other game types like CTF Blitz (changing flag positions), Arena (akin to Quake's Clan Arena)... The maps are gorgeous and vast and the action feels really good, with plenty of weapons to wield (which need to be unlocked though).PROGRESS:UPDATE: Completely overhauled experience system. Now it's far easier for newer players to learn the games because pay-to-win elements have been unlocked. Grinding has been removed, everything not cosmetic is unlocked from the start. The whole loadout system has been rebalanced. So kudos to Hi-Rez.CIRCUMSTANCES:The community playing this game is rather small. Hi-Rez cut support for the game a few years back because it was "complete" (even though there are still bugs that need some work, Hi-Rez mismanaged the game and consequently many players have left the game, but with the rebalancing I highly recommend that you come back.CONCLUSION:+ Fast-paced action+ Beautiful maps+ A rather successful attempt to modernize the Tribes formula+ Not pay-to-win (anymore)- Small number of players for now- Not as easy to pick up as other FPS'sMy rating:8 / 10P.S. After you play few matches to get a grip on the game, I suggest you to head over to tribesascendwiki.com and tribes.wikia.com for class guides and other information and check out playapug.com for finding pick-up games (organized, but casual games).

												Legendary Quake-alike action shooter with great movement freedom. Ski like a wind with speed over 200 m/h or fly up the sky with your jetpack. And in the same time make your enemy regret that they were born. A lot of futuristic weapons give you a opportunity to live through a great fight. No more easy kills. No more lame matches in which you fell asleep. Your skill is everything here. Predict your enemies moves and make him pay for betrayal. Defend bases, flags, points. Destroy enemy lines, steal their flag, kill them. You choose who you want to be. 9 different classes. All unique. All deadly. And all ready for a fight. Easy lvl-up system ensures your fast grow. A lot of psychos that will be your ally our your prey. Say goodbye to realistic and boring FPS and relax in a First Class futuristic action shooter.

, 2012
												It just hasn't been the same since Tribes 2. Ascend has been really dumbed down. No more painting mortar shots for teammates. Only 3 vehicles. Weird classes (multiple classes in each "weight class") that can be further customized with gold. Gold can be purchased and XP can be used to unlock most things (some things like servers can only be rented with gold) but you will need 100,000 XP for most weapons making it impractical to earn. If you really want to play Ascend you will have to pay at some point. Decent attempt at bringing back the classic Tribes - it's not the same though!Update (12/19/14): They have released a GOTY edition/DLC that has all the unlocks. That is the only thing worth paying for - and only if on sale for $19.99. I would check to see how many servers are alive first though.

												   The sense of achievement and closure for theoretical physics that came with the brilliant success of the classical field theory of electromagnetism was short lived. The new technology invented out of the mathematical unification of electricity with magnetism produced copious data about the nature of matter and light that snapped all of the mathematical threads that physicists had just succeeded in tying down.   And after this new data was unraveled and understood and explained using mathematics, the unified worldview of classical theoretical physics became split into two very different views of the universe -- the particle view and the geometric view.Particles and waves   The first sign of trouble was when J.J. Thomson discovered the electron in 1897. Experimentalists began to see data that suggested a model of the atom with negatively charged particles orbiting around a positively charged core. But according to Maxwell's equations, such a system should be physically unstable

On the other hand, this game requires alot of skill to excel, and since this game doesnt have a HUGE player base, all too often you run into people with aimbots and similar hacks which in my opinion, was detrimental to (in combination with the WAY OP sentinel class) the game's ability to take off and become incredibly popular.Recommending to anyone who wants to have alot of fun and wants a challenge.

												This is my second favorite shooter of all time. The high speed of the players, combined with all the weapons having travel time, makes for some very difficult shots. The adrenaline rush of this game is very exciting, and the satisfaction of pulling off that impossible shot is rewarding. The graphics are beautiful, with Ultra settings rivaling top names graphics. On lowest settings, an AMD A8 mobile APU can run it with ease. The gamplay is very good, as i mentioned before. There are several classes, including assault rifle, sniper, and several other classics, along with unique classes. The classes are customizable to a certain degree. This multiplayer in this game is great, and I'm not experiencing any lag at all.A lot of people are saying this game is dead, but that's the farthest thing from the truth. There's still a small community of us who still play and enjoy this game. Yes if it were opened up by the developers or the P2W features were removed it would be way better but this game is still incredibly enjoyable as-is. Definitely recommend this title.

30, 2014
												Tribes Ascend is one of my all time favorite games. It may have all the evils of a FTP but it is still an excellent game. Few things can match up to the feeling of a high speed flag grab, or the satisfaction of a blue plate special. The weapons have enough variety to give everyone something to suit their playstyle, and each holds its own key to mastery. Though not as flexible as mumble or teamspeak, the in game quick-chat system works well to connect players together. The games classes are all unique and fun and give a great variety of ways to play. No class has ever been OP it has always been the weapons. From the thumper to the faze rifles to the MIRV, there has always been a weapon that HiRez has milked for cash; This is the primary source of frustration in the game. The game has strategy speed and skill requirements of any good shooter and though difficult to aproach can quickly become a favorite. I personally do not own the GOTY edition so I am not sure if it levels the playing feild or effects matches that much. Tribes Ascend: Even with its shortcomings and faults is an amazing game and I hope to see a sequel in the near future.

												I can't say if it's better or worse than the metric on which all class-based multiplayer FPSs must be based, TF2. It's a different creature. What makes TF2 great (besides the solid gunplay and hilarious...everything) is the balanced, nuanced interplay between classes, playing to their strengths and weaknesses. What makes this game great (besides the solid gunplay) is the amazing movement system, which lends a ballet-like surreal quality to everything you do.  It's hard to ski down the slope you spawned on, then alternate between skis and jetpack all the way to the center, never dipping below 80 mph (and maybe shooting someone if you find time), but when you do, there's nothing else like it. In most games, I usually play a mid-to-long range explosive projectile person (in the American Revolution, for instance, I'd operate a cannon, and bazookas are a man's best friend), unless the core gameplay suggests something different. Tribes is like that. No way in hell I'm choosing anything other than the Pathfinder class.

3, 2016
												A shooter reminescent of older Arena shooters like Unreal Tourney or Quake, mixed with a class based shooter like TF2, Dirty Bomb, or Overwatch, all tied together with a delicious, adrenaline lined, and frenetic obsession with speed and flag capping. If you like the team oriented action of games like TF2 and Dirty Bomb, and you also like the speed of sonic the hedgehogs, and if you seriously miss older style shooters like UT or Quake, this game is a great way to scratch that itch in a time when those kinds of games are harder to find. Just be warned, the learning curve is very much there; learning to either lead a shot on a Spinfuzor or a Sniper Rifle, or learning how to Jetpack and Ski to effectively capture a flag will take a while to work out if you don't feel confident in you're own abilities. But Bottom line, this is a shooter that feels like it has the grit, backbone, and level of respect belonging to older shooters, while mixed with the technical wizardry, accessibility, and just straight-up fun of more modern shooters. Recommended!

ry 13, 2014
												An Honest review...While I have so far reasonably enjoyed this game, it still has flaws that I want to point out. They aren't too game changing but it pulls me away from saying this game is brilliant. This is just my honest review and it is certainly no hate to the game, I still recommend it.I admire the creativity. I really enjoy skiing, though the original control layout is a little odd. This made me relize that this wasn't just a Halo emulator. I'm not too much of a fan of the jetpack but I think that'll just take getting used to or I just don't like jetpacks at all since I hardly ever use them in Halo Reach and Halo 4 either.The game plays like a good FPS, far better than the quality of the CoD series but it isn't quite up their with my favourite FPS' like Halo and Half-Life but hey it is free.So now I am on to the negatives. I'm sorry fan boys but I want to be honest here. Firstly I personally wouldn't say it quite meets up to the fast gameplay.Yes you can reach high speeds while skiing but even times like that are limited. You probably travel a lot faster in this than in other FPS' but it isn't displayed in a fast paced fashion so you don't feel it. Half-Life feels faster, TF2 feels faster and those games don't advertise their games as fast.That isn't too game changing but it wasn't what I thought it would be. The gameplay just isn't good as the "reviews" say so. It is still fun but I don't like the spaced out approach they used for a "fast paced" game.Also you need almost sniper precision when using an assault rifle... BUT HEY!The game is free and reasonably fun, how can you go wrong?

content:
1, 2016
												I would like to start this by saying that the game isn't bad in regards to controls/graphics/stability, but this games multiplayer (literally all there is aside from training) is absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing ridiculous. If you are okay with playing a game with a steep learning curve, against players you realistically shouldn't be gaming against as a new player, and people that honestly have such a high level of skill it is atrocious they were matched against you? Feel free to download this game, and play it to your hearts content cause that is what you will get.Tribes: Ascend doesn't have an intelligent matchmaking system, it matches anyone against anyones, and doesn't really have a way of matching new players against new players cause FOR SOME REASON no one thought of doing that. Each time I have played this game, which is far more than my steam profile is probably going to display, I have gone up against people that are FAR beyond the skill level of my fellow new players.Despite the fact I have tried to take the time to learn this game, oh lord have I put in the effort to master it, it is realistically impossible for me to do so under the stress of playing against people FAR beyond my skill level, especially when it tends to be an entire team of skilled players. The only way I would EVER go back to this game is if they put in place a system, which a lot of multiplayer games have in recent times, that places you against people at your own levels while restricting people of a higher skill level. They could even add in rewards for people as they go up in the ranks, into higher 'tiers' of skill, and also give an incentive for not making a new account to bypass the tiered matchmaking. Until they do something like that, which I doubt they will since this game doesn't seem to have seen an update in a while, I am never going to install it again.TLDR: Matchmaking puts you against people far beyond your skill level, this game honestly sucks entirely for that reason, and I would only come back if they had a system in place that put you against people at your own level.

												Don't get me wrong, this game is really fun, its a nice new takes on fps games, its fun. But theres some problems that I just can't look past. The Thumper is rediculously overpowered. It isn't even funny, noobs come inwith a weapon that can decimate a vetern squad. It's sad.The spinfuser isnt much better, but atleast you have to aim to a certain extent. The vehicles arent nearly as awesome as Id expect them to be. I can take a tank down no problem as a juggernaut, and its so damn expensive. Shrikes   aren't any better. Grav cycles aren't terrible, they're cheap, go fast, and do plenty of pewpews, but they might as well be made from wet paper. Generator room camping is quite the problem, Ive had it where 3-4 people fly into my gen room, and hold it for the entire round, crippling my teams ability to attack/defend. The issue here is that theres too much cover inside of the generator room, the enemy can use it just as well as allies. Of course, it's been a good year since I've played this, and if its changed, I'll go ahead and update this.

content:
r 8, 2014
												Review time!I will preface by saying that I have played this since beta and I am a huge fan of Tribes. And just because I want to have more people to shoot at, I'm going to recommend this game. I will go into flaws though and what some players who haven't tried this yet may want to keep in mind.Tribes Ascend is a weird tiny beasty... It is a solid game overall, but frankly, HiRez dropped the ball pretty badly. They stopped development on this game completely. They did this in order to pour all resources on Smite, and despite doing something so "♥♥♥♥♥♥" to a rather unique game that only needed a tiny bit of love they also ignored the cries to let the community mod the game. So this means that the main reason the older Tribes games are still around is totally non-existant here. There are no new maps, no new waepons and definitely no new updates coming.What this means for new players is that they are pretty much getting a "complete" game, whether the game itself is complete or not. This is not too bad, to be honest. I can't quite say that it is balanced, when it comes to weapons, and you will most certainly get wrecked by players who played this game longer but I think that is the charm. There are no totally overpowered weapons (even though the sniper rifles and some other weapons can get really annoying) and this is mostly down to how the weapons work. It takes time to get good enough with a weapon to even hit players. It takes even longer to get a Blueplate with a spinfusor (hitting a person in the air with a spinfusor weapon) or just hitting people with the automatic rifles. For me that's what the charm of the game is, there's a lot to do with how good you are at it.Another thing to note is that this game is all about teamwork, you need people to defend your base, some to attack and disrupt the enemy defence, cappers to get the flag and chasers to chase the enemy flag carrier. Ofcourse, this is the optimal setup and doesn't always come into play on pub servers, but sometimes it does. And this is another charm of the game itself, if you are bad at shooting at people, then maybe try your hand at capping the flag. Or if you can't ski that great, can try vehicles or being a juggernaught bombaring the enemy base from far away.All that is all good and well, but the fact that the game is "dead" for the developer is a huge blow. And while I would recommend this to any player who wants a fast, skill-based shooter, I would also say that you might get pretty bored because there's no chance of anything new added or any of the totally crappy maps being changed for the better.

												First of all, let me say something, this game is BEYOND fast paced. The game has a rather unique princible of the "Frictionless suit" Using the suit you have to keep up momentum, or be a sitting duck, it also has a rather steep learning curve in regard to constantly having to head your target and maintaining a constant grasp of where you are in the map and what you have to do, making this game a MUST TRY! 												This is a great free to play game, its very fun and bug free. I do have a few problems.1: VERY VERY VERY steep learning curve. The movment is very fast and all weapons have a projectile speed. You will have to master your predictions of your projectiles to get a good shot.2: Slow progress. Leveling up is slow and hard. A game usually lasts 20 minutes to complete and usually dosent give you much experience.3: It requires a HiRez account to play and that always takes time to get started.But other than that I do recemend trying this. Also your starting items are very good and are mostly meta so you will not be out guned.

content:
2015
												The game itself is very solid and ans some amazing mechanics. The skiing and combat is fast paced and action packed. The main problems lie in the learning curve and the cheaters. T:A offers a tutorial area and guides to get you started, but really you should just play to see what works for you. If you want to do something faster or better, there are YouTube videos of how to do it. Hackers. They're not maggot-infested in the servers but they are a reality. Kicking people is very hard because 80% of the players in-game must agree, and no more than 2 people can vote no. Hi-Rez has 100% completely abandoned this game to work on Smite. There is no longer any form of tech support or patch fixing etc.  If you can work through the learning curve, and find games without hackers, then it's a solid game for those with the patience to play it. However, you're looking for a fun new fps to get into, look away. This one comes with a lot of early game stress and frustration.The F2P model is pretty good, everything in game can be purchased with in-game credits. Premium currency can buy the same weapons and upgrades, but these are balanced and not game-breaking. Everything in this game has a counter to it.

content:
er 20, 2014
												I believe that tribes ascend is a wonderful game. I've tested it on an old laptop with a i5 3210m CPU with Intel HD 4000 graphics and found myself playing the game at around 30fps, with some drops to around 20fps on the odd occasion and on medium graphical settings. This shows the game has been well optimised for lower end computers and can be playable for many people who own either a high or low end PC or laptop.I like the fast paced game movement style, really gets me tired of the normal walking speed on games like battlefield, COD and other first person shooters that are similer. I like the variety of classes and weapons and although you can pay to claim weapons at an early stage, I think that earning them gives you proudness over what you have achieved. I highly recommend this game to all that enjoy zipping around and blasting men in metal suits out of the sky above you and think that although this game has been around for a long time, it still claims a place in the best PC games out there.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 21, 2014
												WARNING: DO NOT JUDGE THIS REVIEW BASED ON HOW MANY HOURS I HAVE, I DOWNLOADED THE DRM FREE VERSION LONG BEFORE I FOUND TRIBES ON STEAM. I've played this game for the longest time, making it one of the first pc games I've ever played since joining Steam. It provides a fast paced combat system, only alloting for quick reflexes and a sharp mind. Due to that, for beginners, especially now, the learning curve can be quite steep but it is well worth it. The graphics are pretty good for a f2p game, however a few graphical glitches can occur on certain video cards that may as well break the game, however it is nothing a little bit of tweaking cant fix. The soundtrack isn't the best I've ever listened to, put it puts a nice tempo into the game. However, it requires alot of concentration, so it is not for those looking for a fun casual game; making playing with friends very tedious. Overall, its a good game that shouldn't be missed or traded in for something like SMITE >:S. Stupid devs.

content:
3, 2014
												What if I told you there was a game that had a unique travel mechanic called skiing and team based battle matches? Well, this is it. Ascend is definitely for those who want to play Multiplayer.  With it being free-to-play the microtransactions can cause pay to win problems. The game is definitly more fun with friends.  Pros:  Decient Multiplayer Experience  Decient number of Classes/Perks  Character/class EXP persistance between matches  Weapon Upgradability  FREE-ish (Ingame microtransactions)  Fast adrenaline pumping action via unique skiing-mechanic  Arena maps with different game modes (CTF, Team death match, etc)Cons:  No SinglePlayer (No Offline, minimun free account required)  Pay to Win (Unless you're good enough)  Things bought with ingame currency is WAY to expensive vs the real money alternativeFinal Suggestion:  Try it out!! See If You Like It Rating:  7/10 Scale:  1 =AVOID [-|-]  2-4 =Try Only if Free [-|-]  5 =Meh, Could be Better  6 =Below Average [-|-]  7 =Average [-|-]  8 =Get if it appeals [-|-]  9 =Get it [-|-]  10 =MUST HAVESee For YourSelf: No video for this one, sorry

content:
, 2015
												Honestly, I'm not completely sure why people are calling this game an abandoned project. Sure, the devs may have quit periodically updating the game, but to be honest, there arren't really any updates needed. This game was good-to-go the second it hit the market. So if you complete something and then not change it, are you really abandoning it? (I'm not meaning to get deep there. :p)As far as servers go, don't think for a second that that there are none. There are LOADS! On top of that, there are different types of servers for every gamemode. You have your Official Servers and your Community Servers. The Officials are pretty straight forward, they're what you'd expect an Official Server to be like. The Community Servers on the other hand are a whole nother story. Some are normal, but others have crazy modifications, like free vehicles, and Orbital Strikes that only cost 1 Credit (You get about 2-500 per kill).Not that it needs to be said, because it should be painfully obvious to anybody even looking at the previews for it, but this game is amazing. On top of that, IT'S FREE!!! I don't see how anybody can complain about a game that is this beautifull and free. If you download this game, I promise, it will slowly begin to consume all of your online life. The adrenaline rush you get in your body as you take the enemy flag while you're flying at 300 km/h is shocking. You'll simply feel your heartbeat in every part of your body. That feeling alone should be enought to make anybody get this game. Even though I only have about 70-80 hours in on this game, they have been the best hours of any game I've ever played. If I had to give an example of a similar game, it would be a combination of Halo (I know, this doesn't come close, but just the look of it reminds me of Reach), and Call of Duty (Yuck) or Battlefield (Better). The shear fast pacing in this game will make anybody want to play it for hours on end.Thanks for reading, and I really hope you at least TRY the game. I mean, it's free. If you don't like it, just delete it. At least all your friends that will still be playing it can't say you didn't try it.

content:
y 21, 2014
												Although the "skiing" system is original and quite interesting, a lack of better class equality and much better graphics (because the graphics of this game are of cube 2 level, and that's a bit of a shame for a new PC game), coupled with a few bugs and annoying glitches like the fact that spawn points are completely random it seems... All in all, you can try this game if you want, well it's free after all, but in my opinion, if you want a really good free FPS game, go play Planetside 2 which is on a completely other level. (well it's not really the same budget to start with).My final rating is 4/10, because it's not because a game is free that anything goes, even if there are some original points and ideas included in the package, I don't consider it to be enough to get more than that rating.
